--- title: "MA22019 2025 - Solutions for Homework 2" subtitle: "Mise en place" categories: ["Homework", "Solutions"] --- Before starting the exercises, make sure to load the dplyr and lubridate R packages: ::: {.cell} ```{.r .cell-code} library(dplyr) library(lubridate) ``` ::: If you are using your own laptop, you may have to first run the code in "InstallPackages.R" (available from Moodle) to install all the packages essential for this course. ### **Homework Question - Salaries for Data Scientists** The file "Salary Data Scientists.csv" provides data for 603 employees working in Data Science / Machine Learning /AI. For each employee, we are given the following information * **work_year** - Year the data were collected for the employee * **experience_level** - Experience Level: Entry-level (EN), Junior (MI), Senior (SE) or Expert (EX) * **employment_type** - Full-time (FT), Part-time (PT) or Contingent Workers (CT) * **salary, salary_currency** - Nominal salary and currency in which it was paid * **salary_in_usd** - Nominal salary in U.S. Dollars * **employee_residence** - Country the employee is residing * **remote_ratio** - Proportion of time the employee may work from home * **company_location** - Location of the company's headquarters * **company_size** - Size of the company: Small (S), Medium (M) or Large (L) An undergraduate is considering to take units in Data Science / Machine Learning / AI. However, they are unsure about the working conditions they are likely to experience if they decide to work in the sector. Specifically, the student plans to work full-time for an U.S. company, and they want to get some insight into the differences between small-/medium-sized and large companies. After a discussion with the student, the following three aspects have been identified as important for them: a) Opportunity to work remotely for at least 50% of the time. b) Salaries for Entry-Level positions. c) Structure of the workforce in terms of experience level. Perform an analysis which considers the three aspects above. Make sure to clearly describe your approach and conclusions.

*We start by loading the data:*

::: {.cell} ```{.r .cell-code} Salary <- read.csv( "data/Salary Data Scientists.csv" ) ``` :::

*Since the student wants to work full-time for a US company, we have to remove any observations that don't refer to a US company and full-time employment:*

::: {.cell} ```{.r .cell-code} Salary_USA <- Salary %>% filter( company_location=="US", employment_type=="FT" ) %>% select( work_year, experience_level, salary_in_usd, remote_ratio, company_size ) ``` :::

*The final step is to convert the information on company size into a binary variable, because we want to compare large companies against the rest:*

::: {.cell} ```{.r .cell-code} Salary_USA <- Salary_USA %>% mutate( size = case_when( company_size=="L" ~ "L", .default = "S/M" ) ) ``` :::

*We are now ready to address the three aspects. Let's start with the ratio of employees that work remotely *

::: {.cell} ```{.r .cell-code} Salary_USA %>% group_by( size ) %>% summarise( "Remote Working" = round( mean( remote_ratio>=50 ), 3 ) ) ``` ::: {.cell-output .cell-output-stdout} ``` # A tibble: 2 × 2 size `Remote Working` 1 L 0.816 2 S/M 0.798 ``` ::: :::

*We find that there are only small differences in the proportion of people that work remotely when comparing companies of different size.*

*For the second part we derive some summaries for the salary in U.S. Dollars:*

::: {.cell} ```{.r .cell-code} Salary_USA %>% filter( experience_level=="EN" ) %>% group_by( size ) %>% summarise( "Median Salary" = quantile( salary_in_usd, 0.5 ), "Average Salary" = mean( salary_in_usd ), "Standard Deviation" = sd( salary_in_usd ) ) ``` ::: {.cell-output .cell-output-stdout} ``` # A tibble: 2 × 4 size `Median Salary` `Average Salary` `Standard Deviation` 1 L 85500 113850 67735. 2 S/M 90000 90222. 25563. ``` ::: :::

*We see that the medium salary for small-/medium-sized companies is larger than for large companies, and that the reverse is true for the average salary. Looking at the standard deviation we see that there is quite a bit of variation in the salary for entry-level positions.*

*Finally, we extract the number of employees at the different experience levels for the different company sizes:*

::: {.cell} ```{.r .cell-code} Salary_USA %>% group_by( size, experience_level ) %>% summarise( Number=n() ) %>% mutate( Proportion = Number / sum(Number) ) ``` ::: {.cell-output .cell-output-stderr} ``` `summarise()` has grouped output by 'size'. You can override using the `.groups` argument. ``` ::: ::: {.cell-output .cell-output-stdout} ``` # A tibble: 8 × 4 # Groups: size [2] size experience_level Number Proportion 1 L EN 10 0.0971 2 L EX 5 0.0485 3 L MI 41 0.398 4 L SE 47 0.456 5 S/M EN 18 0.0741 6 S/M EX 10 0.0412 7 S/M MI 46 0.189 8 S/M SE 169 0.695 ``` ::: :::

*Looking at the numbers, the main difference between small/medium-sized and larger companies seems to lie in the proportion of junior/senior staff. For small/medium-sized companies about 2/3 of employees in the sector are at senior level, while it is less than 1/2 for larger companies.*

**Here is were you should provide a conclusion which addressess the question!**
